review_title: Good place to develop skills but not a place to stay
pros: The pros were a good benefits package and reasonable salary for my first job out of college.  Tuition benefits were the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: The job can become extremely stressful.  The workload revolves around an 8 week schedule of classes, with more stress in the weeks right before classes start to register as many students as possible for classes.  The job can be miserable unless you enroll a large number of students which makes the managers like you.  There is huge pressure to admit and enroll a large number of students. The work schedule was not at all conducive to work/life balance.

pros: Laid back environment, not micro-managed, schedule is flexible
cons: Several inconsistencies in pay structure, you are expected to perform at the same caliber as someone who has 20+ years of experience, and who is paid three times as much as you.  There is no room for growth, the old days are gone where you are compensated based on your enrollment measure.  So those who were not lucky to be in the industry prior to regulations are stuck with a minimal salary.  Another issue is as a campus advisor the initial goal was to enroll students for the campus, and it was both encouraging and uplifting seeing the students walk the hall ways.  However, now the model is pushing a primarily online program...so the campus presence is shrinking and nearly gone entirely.  There seems be a disconnect with the overall direction of where the company wants to be, and what it takes to get there.

pros: The only pros to this organization is leaving it.
cons: Where to start? This organization is corrupt. They're greedy and they don't care one bit about education. They care about the bottom line and treat employees like robots. It is SALES and that is all. Education isn't even in the top 5. They care about selling education at a ridiculous cost and claiming that they're value driven. Their values are making money and being profitable. I feel sorry for students who think they're getting a good education. They won't be able to pay their loans off because they'll never have a job that pays them enough. They prey on low-income students and rope them in to a degree program they can't afford because their expectations are so high they lose sight of their moral compass. All it is a diploma mill with lemmings following orders and producing numbers. They don't care ONE BIT about their employees or their students. They are an embarrassment.

pros: Only reason to work there is the benefits.  They are ok.  However, I would never refer anyone to work at DeVry... even my worst enemy.
cons: Mistreat employees by overworking and underpaying employees.  No room for internal promotions.  It is all politics.  DeVry does not promote based on merit or hard work.  Management is not qualified and just puppets for DeVry, Inc.  They are a joke.  DeVry should be investigated for HR payroll and confidentiality infractions.  The school is unethical in their admissions requirements by requiring all advisors to ask for a referral in every phone call and interview or they are reprimanded.  Admission goals are really unrealistic sales goals.  Promotions and reviews are biased and unfair.  Metro President only cuts budgets and condones layoffs.  The employees voice is unappreciated and unheard.

job_title: Executive Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: they pay fro an admissions rep can be ok IF your able to make to the executive level, which is extremely hard to do. You can expect to make about 52k then. The work is very easy and you can get a free degree.
cons: There is an immense amount of pressure to sale degree programs to individuals who mostly only have a GED, and virtually no interest in getting a degree in anything Devry offers. Its a revolving door also. Employees are ALWAYS quitting or getting a brown box on their desk, and this is from management on down. Theres no loyalty or appreciation for employees. I was told by a Director in  admissions  to use Devry cause they are gonna use you, then spit you out! They were right!

review_title: Good at first then well Power took over
job_title: Admissions Assistant in Federal Way, WA
pros: Had a WONDERFUL manager. Was a student worker and enjoyed my work they allowed me to focus on school when I needed to and helped me out while I was working to build good skills that I now use at my new employement
cons: Well... stuff hit the fan.. And yes there is no other way to put it. The President of our campus gets butt hurt alot! and I sent in my two weeks notice because I got a full time position and she got all butt hurt  and the moment my grades slip due to major family issues she wouldn't allow me back.  MIND YOU I worked for them for almost 2 years (which is longer the most full time employees)

job_title: Student Finance Consultant in Wood Dale, IL
pros: Great healthcare benefits, amazing PTO
cons: Constantly making dumb changes, no concern for the students or employees, evil company, only cares about profit.

review_title: A great place to start a career...
job_title: Admissions Advisor II in Naperville, IL
pros: In short, Benefits are good (healthcare, dental, vision, 401K, Profit Sharing, etc.), Salary is more than competitive for the industry (starting 40-43K/year), Very valuable training and skill development in this position.  Skills translate into: RECRUITING, SALES, MARKETING, CALL CENTER MANAGEMENT, ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT, HUMAN RESOURCES, BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT, etc.
cons: Morale is somewhat negative. Many disgruntled colleagues because of lack of advancement opportunities.  Hours can be inconvenient and schedules are particularly inflexible.  9-6 M-Th with 1 late night (10-8), out at 4 on Fridays, and one mandatory Saturday per month.  Also, this job is very monotonous, 3 years in and the job responsibilities have not changed much.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Pomona, CA
pros: * Pay was competitive. * I loved my co-workers, and to this day they are still my friends. * I had great supervisors in my department. * I was able to take time off when sick.* Gave me a job during the bad economy.
cons: * Laid off, after 4 years, no one went over severance package with me, escorted me out of the building immediately. After signing severance package would not rehire me, even thought i was a loyal employee with a good record. Decisions were made on making profits, not what was best for students.

review_title: Do not work for this company.. Mistreat people..only care about making money...
job_title: Senior Admission Advisor in Pomona, CA
pros: many locations ..strategically place schools off the freeways.. that all do not have much good to say about..
cons: Upper management too much micro management.. Lost sight of the focus which is the students ..It is all about making money..& not about the students... extremely brutal to their advisors...if you do not meet your goals.. Marketing is absolutely the worst.. The lead generation is awful...They do not care about the community..it is all about the money...You got high level managers making way too much money for this school.. Need to lay off top brass not low level employees...again it is about profit not students..

job_title: Manager Local Accounts in Fresno, CA
pros:
Great tuition benefits - employees get free tuition after working for the company for 6 months.
Good place for people starting their career or finishing their careers
cons:
-Struggling industry
-Very little advancement opportunity
-No vision or direction, constant course correction
-Negotiate well for your starting salary, because once you start, they make it very hard to get an increase.  I know people who've been working for years without an increase.  
-Company limits internal promotions to a 10% pay increase regardless of the position advancing to
-They favor external hires, and don't promote internally
-Training is non-existent, which is why the prefer to hire from others within the industry
-Employee culture is poor, most of my colleagues are looking for other jobs

review_title: In general a good place to work.
pros: Currently in 2013 there is now room for advancement and training that was not available before. Admissions department pay has been lowered, but so has the workload for a more balanced work life. Academic departments are more streamlined and not as confusing as it once was during the time of my employment there.  If you have the right management in place, it can be a great place to work.
cons: The problems can be favoritism which ran rampant during my employment period of 2004 - 2009.  And accountability for one's own work, and plenty of management back door dealings that we're borderline libel. From what I've seen and heard as of now, some of those practices have been eliminated, or they have taken strides to get ride of it.  Unfortunately, there are still some bad seeds in the company.

pros: Decent base pay, selling education to people who might never have gone to school, "warm" calling environment, tuition reimbursement, decent 401k
cons: Selling people who might never have gone to school a very expensive education that likely will not last past the 2nd semester. Forcing these people to take out massive student loan debt, fratty environment, typical sales mentality, 100 avg calls a day, 8 hours avg talk time a week, etc. Quotas are extremely high based on the expense of the product your selling.. .etc

review_title: I wouldn't wish this on my worst enemy!
pros: Nice coworkers. Good benefits. They are expensive but decent. You can choose your healthcare options. They have employee get togethers twice a year, such as at the zoo or dave and busters.
cons: This is a corporation, don't let the word "university" fool you. You will be managed by sales managers, in every department of this organization. It's not about the student, or lower level employees, it's about the company and the money they make. Low level employees are not treated well. Rude managers will fire you for the slightest infraction, which could be, not following the script when talking to students. It's that bad. Non existent raises and managers covering their own job run rampant here. I even found a power point from a manager making fun of the people who put together an awards ceremony. You will never move up. Ever.

review_title: Lost focus leads to declining enrollment
pros: The pay rate and benefits are acceptable, and the classroom and online resources are also very acceptable.
cons: Enrollments are way down at DeVry and depending on the chicken and the egg scenario, this has either led to a complete loss of focus or vice versa.  The verbally articulate that the student is "first", but their actions are completely contrary.  Faculty are the best promoters of the school, and they have gone to a model of promoting mostly online classes with adjunct faculty, who are not paid for the work they do, and thus don't put in the time needed to affirm the student-centric focus needed to achieve their "student first" mission.

pros: Pros, the insurance is good, my co-workers are very friendly. I can't say enough about the people, most of them are top knotch.  If it's your first job out of college, you can excel here if you're into sales. Cafeteria with hot food, and they offer flexible hours for certain positions.
cons: It's a business first, then a university. I wish I had known, it literally kills me to go to work everyday knowing these poor people can go to a community college and pay thousands less. The jobs are menial, low pay, and highly repetitive. Managers have zero management experience and do not care about you, it's about "the business". You have very little chance of moving up the ladder. Work from home is offered as a perk but never given.

review_title: A challenging environment that above all pushes a student focused approach.
pros:
DeVry offers a great benefit package that is put in place from day one.  They also give their employees the opportunity to buy up (5) extra vacation days, on top of the 5 that they already provide.

Another great reason to work for DeVry is you co-worker.  They do a great job of bringing in a wide range of individuals that create a healthy and diverse work environment.
cons: The opportunity  for growth was always shaded.  Although the industry has gone through extreme changes over the last year the chance to move up within the position was never clearly provided.

review_title: Not a great place to work.
job_title: Student Services in Rego Park, NY
pros: Was able to gain experience working with college students.  Met some really cool co-workers who became friends.  Many different responsibilities to add to my resume.
cons: Terrible work life balance.  Constantly adding job responsibilities. Shortly after I left they extended office hours to 9pm which would keep an employee at work all day.  It was horrible for people who had families.  They also started forcing employees to work on "alternate holidays".

pros: Helping students reach graduation and at one time the people working there.
cons: The home office I a bit out of touch. They spent millions on an Olympic partnership to so they can be visible in Brasil where they are currently making money. Truthfully these students aren't interested in that - the money would've best been served to update the technology and invested back at the campus level of the company. Instead there were cutbacks until it actually hurt  the students , the staff, the resources. DeVry is truly a joke now. The reputation is as bad as the punch lines about them on sitcoms and movies.

review_title: I've passed 11 out of 16 papers required to qualify my MBA from DeVry University, remaining 5 papers are in progress.
job_title: Professor of Accounting I in Downers Grove, IL
pros: MBA from Keller Graduate School of Management is a comprehensive managerial qualification. It is innovative and gives problem-solving and decision-making skills.It enables a qualified person  to control and run an organisation successfully.
cons: The cost of the course is very high. DeVry University is a 'for profit' institution and the charge per subject is around $2700. Therefore one needs to spend over $100,000 for the course feews and living expenses.

pros: The salaries are on par with the industry average. The local managers are carrying and considerate. The corporate executives are rapacious and out of touch with the education that occurs in the classroom.
cons: Although the salaries are good, DeVry makes professors work for that money, requiring a teaching load of 45 credit hours per year. Way too much control is exerted on classroom instruction from the center; home office doesn't permit professors to make local and tailored decisions about instructional content.

pros: I have been with DeVry for almost a decade for a reason: it is simply a great company to work for. There are plenty of means of support, and work is steady - not always predictable, but steady. It is a company that runs smoothly and efficiently.
cons: The main downside is really true of most educational institutions and the general life of an adjunct; workload is not always predictable. And salary does not really change, but it is still pretty decent.

pros: Have been with Devry over 5 years, great co-workers!  Full time professors that truly care for their students.  Seeing students getting a chance at college that may not have otherwise.
cons: Sudden mass lay offs which are common now in the company, I'm one of 100+ full time faculty laid off without warning. Management is very deceptive in their practices.  More focused on bottom line, than the needs of the students.  They forget they are a university first and not a business first.

pros: DeVry University has an exceptionally talented workforce. It's advisors, student services staff, and throughout iot's local campuses. It's reputation as an industry leader in IT is truly deserved. hey have an extremely experienced faculty which is an asset tot he organization
cons: Highly conservative in innovative approaches. DeVry strives to compete with cutting edge technologies to integrate within the classroom. The only issue is that they overly regulate themselves. It's a double-edged sword. On one hand it keeps the company out of the negative spotlight. However, as a University they are struggling to keep up with innovative technologies to enhance an overall student experience. Universities that utilize Open courses, self-paced instruction, certification programs within their undergraduate degree programs far outweigh what DeVry is offering. Plus, the tuition is very costly.

review_title: What is really happening at the devry Fresno campus!
pros: Good pay in DEM but low pay in other departments
cons: local leaderships don't know the business thus not being able to help train the employees to service the students! Cost of tuition is too high so Devry targets low income and uneducated parents to sale them the American dream!  Leaders working at the local Campus would not dare let their kids attend DeVry or let people know they work at DeVry but yet preach to employees about how proud they are for DeVry!  It's sad that this is happening in our Fresno community and needs to be stop!

review_title: It was fantastic, but some of that fire has gone out.
job_title: Academic Tutor/Administrative Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: The office is small and really works well together. When I first started working with them, it felt like a little family, the staff and faculty genuinely care about each of their students and it shows in how students respond.
cons: The management from another campus took over this campus, and when that happened, some of that "family" feel wasn't there anymore. Most of the time, it felt like the management from the other campus was only there because they had to be there, they didn't take on ownership of the campus like the prior management had, and since then, the campus size has gotten smaller and smaller.

job_title: Operations Support Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great company, Pay is on time, team is awesome, folks at other locations awesome. Once you are set up with everything it is a smooth work environment. If you have a chance to work for DeVry you will love the people. Students are usually to always nice. Once in a while there is an issue, but the teams pull together to answer the students questions/issues.
cons: Learn on your own. Very on job training learn as you go. You have to take a test to be certified worker. LOTS OF HURRY UP AND WAIT, to begin. It took 3 weeks to get set up with all credentials, log ins and passwords.

review_title: Help Desk / Technical Services Support II
job_title: IT Help Desk Technician in Henderson, NV
pros: Strong work /  Life balance. Decent benefits, profit / success sharing, talented team members and environment. Opportunities to assist students to achieve educational goals.
cons: Students sometimes aren't serious about education and only want to enroll in classes to get their financial aid and end up wasting time and resources that other students may need, Occasional teachers that aren't as serious about teaching or maybe they are and just don't do it well (this has been noticed recently and management RIF'ed  large amount of low quality teachers for long term bad performance)

review_title: If you work for them, you never know when you will become unemployed
pros: tuition benefits for full time employees. I also heard that health insurance is really good but I am not sure since I have never used it.
cons: You never know when you will get fired no matter how hard you have worked for the company.  The company needs people who understands and values education. Also the management keeps a lot of secrets. By the time you learn what is going on, it is very late. Either your job is 10 times harder now or you are expected to accomplish something unrealistic or you actually don't have a job.

review_title: Great job with the right manager
pros: If you end up with a good manager, there are lots of opportunities at DeVry and people are very focused on helping students.
cons: With the wrong manager, are there are lots, anything goes. I've had 4 managers at DeVry: two good and two bad. The bad ones make me want to quit while the good ones made me think I had the best job ever. There are lots of metrics at DeVry and everything is watched. A lot of people spend too much time trying not to get flagged instead of trying to do good work.

review_title: My experience with DeVry has been both positive and rewarding
job_title: Network Operations Center Technician in Oak Brook, IL
pros: DeVry has a lot of friendly people to work with in a very nice looking and open environment.  They also pay really well and have some pretty good benefits such as free schooling for full-time employees.  They are also very open to hiring talented individuals into other departments if the individual is interested.
cons: A downside is that some employees have to work 50+ hours a week or have to be on call for issues that occur and those things affect the home life of the employee.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Columbus, OH
pros: Great teams at the campuses. Mostly everyone was working toward the common goal of satisfying students. People worked hard for the university's mission.
cons: Little to no opportunities for advancement, and favoritism is a major factor. Awful micromanagement from upper management. Upper management has no idea about what really happens at campuses and therefore makes poor decisions for the campuses, their employees, and their students. In an effort to stay current, the company makes so many changes that employees absolutely cannot keep up. It leaves the students and the employees feeling lost.

pros:
Decent pay and good benefits for an entry level position
Catered food regularly and some events outside of work
Good learning experience for someone furthering a career in sales
cons:
If you weren't in the "Click" then you were viewed as an outsider
Took a lot of heat with the recent media attention on for profit universities
Very little "Advising" this is definable a sales job
Work can be very tedious and redundant.  Can burn out quickly
Based on graduation rates, statistically the student would not complete his or her degree at our location
Unsettling feeling knowing you were enrolling a student that was statistically not going to complete their degree
Little upward mobility

review_title: Not much to gain from here
job_title: Student Finance Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits, great people to work with, lots of options for horizontal movement, plenty of locations to transfer to (Chicago area)
cons: Very micromanaged in finance department, constant changes (downsizing, moving to new locations), limited vertical movement, poor training (you rely more on the people who have been here a long time to teach you things than you do from trainers or managers)

pros: Very well defined vision and TEACH values.  Good people with all the right intentions and a strong focus on students who might not otherwise be going to college.  Every program offered has a career path which really affords those who graduate a good future
cons: Constantly having to adjust to the pressures being brought on the for-profit sector of high education has caused constant changes in administration approaches and structure.  Focus is still on education but too often the business side of things gets in the way.

job_title: Admissions Advisor I in Naperville, IL
pros: Free education and good benefits. Other than having a job there are no real pros for this job. The pay is ok and it could be worse in this economy but I do not know many people that enjoy what they are doing
cons: lack of communication, no accountibility from managment, lie about hours and job duties. Very high turnover rate. Long hours. The for-profit educational industry is haveing a really hard time in the current market. Enrollments are consistently declining, the education provided is a joke, and the cost to attend the school is outragious. Don't walk, run form ths company if you are looking at a job as an admissions advisor.

pros:
It's great as a student to be able to work on your campus.  There's no worry about travel, you can make it to class on time, and I was in a great location for lunch and shopping options if I needed to pick something up during the day.

I also had a wonderful supervisor!
cons: Depends a lot on the students and teachers; some of the students would wait until the last minute to come and ask for help, putting us in an impossible situation as they raced to meet a deadline.  Some just wanted us to give them easy answers.

pros: Pay is better than most other institutions for part-time faculty. The class setting is blended, which gives you the flexibility to teach online and onsite. This also opens opportunities for full-time online teaching. Not overwhelmed with meetings or extracurricular duties. Flexibility to teach when I feel like it.
cons: Though I am a DeVry employee, I teach at the Chamberlain College of Nursing. We do not interact with Chamberlain faculty, so it seems as if we are outsiders borrowing time and space on their campus. The DeVry faculty have little interaction also. There is little to no room for advancement or career development. High turnover rate for science faculty.

pros: At first, everyone was really friendly and helpful. The job wasn't too stressful and the pay was decent for a student worker position.
cons: After the first two sessions, working around my schedule took less priority. I had a lot more responsibilities than originally discussed without a raise. I also wasn't allowed to do work in my spare time as originally promised. When I decided to leave, my superiors forgot to turn in my time sheet leaving me with the troubles of having to go through a different bank to get a card with my money that I couldn't transfer to my account without a fee. Everything just went south, and it has continued to go south.

review_title: Students make it a great place to work
pros: Many of the students at this campus are the first ones in their family to go to college, and have had to overcome lots of obstacles that a typical college student doesn't even consider. To be part of the team helping them to graduate and move themselves and their family up the ladder is a great feeling.
cons: It's hard to foster a school spirit when it's an all-commuter school. The old-timer employees here have often given up on the whole idea of education and seem to see it as just another job.

job_title: Financial Aid Representative in Wood Dale, IL
pros: Very laid back environment, not much pressure. Very high margin for error. Lax dress codes and jeans Fridays. Not a lot of management supervision, you're pretty much allowed to do as you please as long as your work is finished. Good benefits package.
cons: Compensation is somewhat lacking; work is tedious and not very challenging. Easy to burn out on the overtime you have to work. There's a lot of grey areas when it comes to the work; some projects you don't know whether it is correct or incorrect due to poor feedback.

pros:
Nice work atmosphere
Friendly staff and co-workers
Strong dedication to military
Good communication amongst teams
Good managerial concern/input in individual performance
cons:
The training they give could be more inclusive of real world instances that happen on the phones.
Sometimes it is difficult to find the information needed to answer questions.  If you work late (past 4PM) it is hard to find a manager.

review_title: DeVry University continues to improve not only it's educational offerings, the way in which it treats its employees.
pros: It provides its employees good pay, good advancement opportunities and above all it cares about it's employees.
cons: The starting pay is great, but getting a respectable raise is difficult.  You're expected to meet certain performance goals that are at best hard to attain great scores in.

review_title: It's a paycheck but hard to sleep at night
pros: If you were on a good team the culture could be fun. It was fairly laid back and not too difficult to navigate the processes, easy to lear the systems etc.
cons: You were selling education to people mostly based on financial aid. The programs were more expensive than the max federal loan amounts, so you were putting people in a position to start a education path that they wouldn't be able to finish if they did not have another way of paying.

pros: Telecommuting, good learning management system
cons: Inconsistent course scheduling, no mentoring, poor benefits

review_title: Could be better, and has been in the past, but not awful
pros: Students are great to work with
cons: Seems to be on a fast downhill slide.  Classes are getting smaller and smaller, but I do not know why.  DeVry seems to be one of the more ethical companies in for profit education and they make an effort at making decisions in the best interest of their students.  But the campus is getting really lonely.

review_title: Soulless, money-grubbing, micromanaging, the worst place I ever worked
job_title: High-level Administrative in New York, NY
pros: The company is profitable, and will probably remain in business longer than other "Dead men walking" in the for-profit educational industry
cons: DeVry is a for-profit university. It does not matter what word follows for-profit, however. This is a miserly, pinched view of the world. You will receive little training, and you will quickly come to understand that it is not about mission, it is not about respect, it is not about the students, it is simply about profit, without regard to how it is earned.

review_title: Enjoyed it, wish I didn't have to leave!
pros: The people I worked with were fantastic and they also had a good training program. Chris Vock was great. Seems like they do have a solid path to growth with the company Academic advisor I, II, III, team lead, supervisor etc. The only reason I left was due to relocating across the country,  but I still keep my eyes open for any job openings at DeVry in NC.
cons: I worked at the Naperville Call Center, and it does get slightly repetitive. You have at least a few calls each day that the students are VERY angry and will cuss at you.

pros: Mostly freedom to determine classroom experience with students. Good environment to teach, good coworkers. Curriculum was good. Students were getting a good education.
cons: Micro managing from corporate. Too much focus on keeping students enrolled and not enough on making sure they learn. If corporate had supported the existing programs instead of just the newest, the existing programs would not have collapsed.

job_title: Admissions Advisor I in Naperville, IL
pros:
A lot of people are playing the position out to be a whole lot worse than it really is. Honestly, I think its all about perspective. If you feel like a salesman, you are going to come off like a salesman, have less success, and hate this job for being a sales position. 

Management is great. Very understanding, really tries to work with you. They do set "goals" which can feel like quotas but realistically, if you do not meet these goals but are still putting forth the effort they are looking for, you are still praised. 

Benefits and pay are great. I have no degree and only retail and food service management experience. They tend to hire based on personality and your ability to build relationships with strangers.

There is really a heavy psychologically aspect to this job and the interactions you have with students. But honestly, it comes from such a positive place. Many of DeVry's students are looking to go back to college to improve something in their lives because they are now working adults looking for reliable online education with a flexible schedule to suit their lives. It is very different than a role at a traditional campus or a public college where majority of your students are high school grads. You have to be able to encourage these adults who have often not had the best experiences in life. This is always easier to do when you have the right perspective about the job. It can be challenging to get personal with a stranger and to keep them motivated on moving forward in their lives and pursuing their education without feeling emotionally exhausted in this role. But those students who are successful appreciate the push you gave them and that feeling is rewarding enough to continue doing the job!
cons:
Since moving to a fully remote environment back in March 2020 due to Covid, I will say, a lot of the management team focuses on nitpicking and monitoring calls. This can make it feel like they are micromanaging and can raise your anxiety on talking to future students as well. That being said, management is always very open to feedback provided its organized and thoughtful and not just complaints. 

We are also told very often that its not about numbers but is more about changing lives. That being said, we are led to feel like we failed when the numbers do not meet our "goals". I think this is improving with time as well but honestly, at the end of the day, this is a privately run college and incoming money is important to grow our staff and business. I have told prospective students that I did not think it was a good idea to register them without clearance from financial aid and have been supported by management in doing so.

review_title: No loyalty and burning out of employees
pros: The organization offers good salaries and fair pay for industry.  The benefits are pretty standard and they match your 401k contribution.
cons: The environment is toxic and the organization doesn't really care when their employees raise concerns.  The leadership professes to hold certain values, but it doesn't trickle down to the staff environment.   When serious issues come to light, the organization shies away from dealing with the management that is responsible, if the locations are still making profits.

pros:
DeVry is a great place to work. The people are nice, friendly, professional and I was treated like family. They offer annual raises to keep up with inflation. The overall atmosphere in my position was positive and a fun place to work.

One thing DeVry is good at doing is providing professional development opportunities for its employees. Whether it is trainings or giving us opportunities to be a part of projects that will help us grow. I really appreciate that now as I do not get that at my current job.
cons: The dynamic started to change towards the end of my time at DeVry. There ended up being a lot of layoffs and no options to transfer positions.

job_title: Student Finance Representative in Oak Brook, IL
pros: With all of the overtime, pay was okay. Benefits including health and 401K are very good. Able to roll over some vacation time and allow employees to buy more vacation time. DeVry is quick to promote  within same department and give raises.
cons: Some management is great others are horrible, depends on the departments. A lot of employees leave and then come back to company. I had to work 50 hour weeks in order to get decent pay. DeVry doesn't like to promote outside an employees current department. They would rather loose the employee all together.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I'm currently having a hard time thinking of pros beyond the students that I met and the relationships I formed with them. Oh and there's a lot of free food..
cons: For profit university with no care about the students, the education, or their employees. No work life balance, constant changes in staff, expectations, and rules. Hours of dials and sales, not helping people. The value of the education doesn't match the cost that students pay. Employees live in fear of lay-offs and management's mood swings. No upward mobility even though it is promised.

review_title: Nice Job if you can get it
job_title: Associate Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It was a good place to work. The students were motivated, and the teaching tools were excellent. They have a solid idea of where each course fits in the progress of the student, and they seem pretty committed to doing their best by them.
cons: The metrics for success in a teaching position were not well articulated, which resulted in my losing my position for a reason of which I am not sure of. The annual rating process is flawed and subjective, making it difficult to actually decide what you need to do to achieve your annual goals.

review_title: Great training, poor demonstration of appreciation for employees
pros: This was a great way to start my career. The online admissions department provided solid pay and benefits (and the benefits started my first day of employment!), fantastic training, and hired good people.
cons: The problem is that they overworked their admissions staff by pushing them for more and more students which lead to an incredibly high turnover rate. It was very hard to be promoted unless you were friends with the right people, even if you consistently put out good work.

pros: Great benefits and salary.  Good school to work for.
cons: Poor management from headquarters.  Constant changing of policies create knowledge gaps.  Metrics are made to satisfy shareholders who only want more money, creating stressful metrics.  No one listens to those experienced, only those with high positions.  My understanding is that things have not changed since I left.

job_title: HS Programs Representative in Houston, TX
pros: flexible work schedule, employees, salary/benefits
cons: constant change, higher up management was heartless with employees during layoff

pros: Great salary and ease of getting onboard.  HR Specialist assigned to recruit was great at staying in touch and following through to keep the process smooth.  She arranged telephone conference calls with three Senior decision-makers in three timezones; set-up the out-of-state interview and everything happened as she said it would. This was a very impressive hiring model.
cons: Corporate office makes all the decisions and each Campus implements. 90% of the time, the decision was an inappropriate action for our campus making the local leadership seem impotent, and unintelligent. Poor students were recruited for science and technology programs who had 10% chance of success and then put the responsibility of the faculty to "make them successful"

review_title: Where mediocre people get paid the same as the stars
job_title: Undergraduate Academic Advisor in Naperville, IL
pros: Excellent training program that fuklly prepared you before being placed live in your role. Benefits start day one. Frequent employee recognition gatherings and events.
cons: Promotions not posted, Senior management decides who they like the best and then moves them into supervisor roles. Annual reviews are a joke, everyone received the same raise, even those who are frequently praised for their outstanding contributions. Doesn't make any employee want to go the extra mile.

pros: DeVry is a team based, data driven, customer friendly environment.  DeVry  puts the team first, appreciates diverse points of view, assume positive intent, collaborates and communicates openly.
cons: Too Many RIFFs within the past 4 years.  I know that times are tough in the For Profit education environment, but there are just so many Reductions in Force.  It would be better to re-align goals and help DeVry to regain their edge in Technology rather than eliminating jobs.

review_title: They say “empowerment” but have hindering practices
job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: When you’re meeting numbers, life is good. Great 401k. Some great colleagues who believe in the power of education.
cons: Health benefits (copay is ridic). Promotion guidelines change often without warning. You are reprimanded for not having applications or starts, which is an illegal practice. New management has created a cutthroat SALES environment, focused on getting anyone in school even if they aren’t a good fit.

pros: Good pay for a first job out of college, it is a very good school to go to and you get close with your co workers.
cons: It's a very hardcore sales environment and they sell lies to the employees too. They tell you they want to promote you and develop you and that it's not all about the numbers but that's a load of bull. They tell you that you don't have to have big numbers in order to get promoted because they recognize other skills you have but it's crap. I had more management experience than my manager AND his manager. But when I asked repeatedly to get into the management program I was constantly told that I needed more "advisor" experience and training. This was after they told me in the interview that I was being hired into the management training program and I could expect a promotion in 6-12 months after I got a little experience. They said they didn't care how many students I got in as long as I put my skills on display they would recognize talent. I developed a training presentation, by myself, with zero assistance from anyone. It was awesome and a few managers told me they would push that up to higher management. What happened after I gave the presentation? My manager stole it, took the credit for it started giving the presentation himself and is still using it, a year after I left the company. I never gave the presentation again. Why? I wasn't hitting my numbers. Bottom line, it's a high school environment with rumors, gossip, and all the male managers sleeping with the cute girls just hired out of college. And the only way to have a chance at doing something other than being a minion is to be one of the cool kids or to put 20 students in every session. I couldn't run out of this place fast enough after a year and a half. I needed something more professional and serious for my career aspirations

pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation time, non teaching session and health/dental and vision insurance.  Good colleagues, management are nice people and genuinely care about you, at least at the local campus level, above that, not so much.
cons: We are required to teach 47 credits a year (over five sessions)!  That is got to be the highest I have ever seen.  Constant cut backs, customer service mentality over academic excellence.  Compensation is MUCH lower than the local and national averages.

pros: Some convenience can be found in certain positions within the company.
cons:
Managers discourage internal communications by requiring permission to address others in the company.
Employee creativity discouraged. Management specifically asks employees not to think. They just want them to do exactly as they are told.
There is absolutely no upward mobility at DeVry. If you don't like what you are doing today, good luck. You are going to be doing it for a long, long time unless you leave the company.
They don't share any of the success with their employees. People work to enrich the upper managers. There is no stock participation. There are no options.

review_title: A good company in a tough industry
pros: The company has amazing benefits and strives to be the best in the industry.  I believe that the professionals at DeVry truly care about their students.  They are incredibly passionate and want to make a difference.  The best part about working here is that incredible student that you encounter that completely changes your life.
cons: The media has not been kind to the for-profit industry the last few years. With as much effort as the company tries to be a step ahead of bad press, they seem to still get lumped into the same bucket as the rest.

pros:
-Competitive starting salary 
-Good benefits package/ 401 K
-Enough Cosi and Corner Bakery to last a lifetime
-Once invested, you can take classes towards earning your masters for free..... sort of.  Apparently new tax guidelines limit the amount of "free" tuition an individual can receive in a given time period.  If you go over the amount ,you will end up paying taxes on the "free" tuition as if it was part of your income for that year.  Basically if you want to complete your masters  for "free" and avoid any tax ramifications.... your going to be there a long long while!
cons:
-Don't let the "admission advisor" title fool.  The most advising you'll do is telling prospective students how quickly they should start.
-Very little help from management with resolving issues in a timely manner.
-Management is concerned with one and one thing only.... Enrollment!  
-Extremely low gradation rates weigh heavily on your morals.  Statistically the students you enroll have a very low chance of completing their program.
-Low admission standards allow for students who do not posses the skills nor work ethic needed to be successful in college to take on tremendous amounts of student loan debt and in most cases never compete their degree.  Bottom line is tax payers are footing the bill because of poor admissions standards.

review_title: It was good while it lasted.
pros: The overall compensation plan is at or above industry standards. The benefits program including 401K match by the company is fairly comprehensive. Salary is above that of most companies in this industry.
cons: The culture is changing and the organization is under a lot of pressure to grow new and continuing student population. There have been far too many lay offs recently that makes for a difficult work environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Some people are good to work with. It's very political. It was a stable company to work. They truly believe they help students.
cons: DeVry University has been a very conservative institution. Unfortunately, it relies on legacy thinking by long tenured leaders who don't seem open to new ideas. Organizational structure is in flux as a result of new senior leadership. DeVry like other for-profit higher education businesses is in a state of transition and is unclear where it will be in 5-10 years.

review_title: Fairly good company to work for.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Recognized top performers and promoted, I enjoyed the people I worked with, provided professional development opportunities.
cons: Very heavy emphasis on recruiting and starting students, but not making sure they are successful and graduate, not sure how valued a degree is from this institution so often felt like I was misleading people to complete a degree when I wasn't sure how it was viewed by potential employers.  Middle management was not great.

review_title: It was great, but hired wrong leadership
pros:
I worked as High School Presenter. Having the flexible schedule and working with student.
Technology in the Classroom Presentation as well as the Advantage Academy  which they had in 2 states.
Discounts on grad schools.
Out of all the For-Profit schools they did it the right away. Accredited, and like any other 
University.
If you are fresh out of college its not a bad gig
cons:
Too Many: ( Should have left at 4 years) Got suckered by the money
Redundancy in task.
Minorities were rarely promoted so unless you were a white male or attractive white female then forget it. The Current Director of Channel Admissions has never done admissions but they promoted her over the Hispanic bilingual male who has 9 years of admissions experience. So if you are white male they will keep you and promote you.


Poor Leadership. The University never made it a priority to track what students came from what high schools. When we went into the homes, we had a better understanding of where are students came from. When we went to the Presenter/ Closer model we lost that.  As Presenters when Counselors asked what students from previous years classes were attending the University we could only say " I do not know." or " A few" but we had no idea.

Lastly the University opened too many campuses too quickly and never concentrated on the Quality of Life of the students. Athletics, Student Groups,etc. Just a new presentation does not answer the questions of " For- Profits Schools"

We went from 16 week classes to 8 week classes. 12 weeks would have been ideal but shoving too many classes into a tight frame.

review_title: Diploma Factory - Felt Bad for Students Who Wasted Their Money
pros: I loved my immediate coworkers.  We were a close group and that helped me get through all the craziness.  I also really liked my immediate boss.  The student workers who worked in our office were also a great group. The building was also kept nice with fresh paint and pretty landscaping.  Plenty of easy parking, too.
cons:
The biggest problem was how embarrassed I felt for working at DeVry.  I knew the money that the students were paying for tuition and how they truly felt a degree from DeVry was more meaningful - or just as meaningful - as a degree from another college.  Here are some of the reasons for my embarrassment:

ACT Scores: I dealt with a lot of the ACT scores of students who were already admitted into DeVry.  Note that I wrote "already admitted".  The vast majority of ACT scores that I saw were 9's or 12's for the Math category of the ACT.  When I saw a "15" for the math category every so often, it stood out for being "high".  Then, there would be students who had a "24" for their ACT score.  I felt bad that they were admitted just as much as those who received a "12".  When a school takes students with incredibly low ACT scores, that's a sure sign that it's a diploma factory.

Transcripts: My advice for anyone who requests a copy of their transcript from DeVry (and especially Keller Graduate School of Management) is to look it over very carefully.  The system that produced transcripts (at least back when I was there) was notorious for having the wrong grades and cumulative gpa.  Especially for Keller transcripts, the computer would sometimes list a cumulative gpa of 0.00.  

The Terrible Trimester System: The school does a trimester system.  And then each trimester is broken into two parts: Session A and Session B.  This allows a student to cram through more classes in less time, but it's a financial nightmare.  If a student attends just one class and then drops the class, they already will already have to pay a significant amount of money.  This system also made it more confusing for employees who were trying to assist students.

review_title: Academia can take the fun out of teaching if you aren't careful.
job_title: Associate Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
+ Great opportunities for teaching
+ Quality processes keep the organization oriented on improvement
+ A business focus on profit keeps company goals grounded and realistic, not choked by academic certifications
+ Good core values that encourage teaching
+ Fantastic staff and part-time faculty, hired without the arduous filters that state academic institutions require, but instead hired based on practical experience and (inadvertently) altruistic desire to teach
+ Excellent opportunities to reach out to students and genuinely improve lives
+ DeVry's focus on developing practical job skills is really solid, and very helpful for students, and makes me feel good to be a part of
cons:
- Meaningless promotions for faculty members
- Quality of campuses varies significantly from site to site
- Disconnected administration that makes decisions on behalf of the business, not the education of students
- Poor administrative support for developing faculty. We are a school for goodness sake, we know how to develop people!
- Immature approach to new course development.
- All courses rely on their eCollege implementation, which probably still has room for improvement.
- All problems are magnified with Online curricula, where faculty have less interaction with students.
- Clear, yet unspoken focus on profit (as opposed to a genuine corporate focus on student education), which hurts the brand
- A culture of jumping through hoops rather than really pushing to make a positive difference (pretty standard bureaucracy)

pros:
Free tuition for classes
Lots of independence in your position.
cons: Unfortunately, DeVry is not a very good school academically so that free tuition program is useless. There is little to no opportunity for advancement here. Although the base pay starts out quite high, it is hard to get a raise and if you don't hit your admissions goals, management can even take away some of your pay. Overtime is strongly encouraged, yet the company only pays half time for all over time hours worked.

review_title: I worked there for a long time while finishing two degrees and took on more than was expected without any recognition.
pros:
Ability to make a difference in the lives of students.
Most of the people that work there are good people overall.
cons:
No praise, recognition, or incentive to work hard or stay an employee there. There was no room for growth. 
You would think that the university would want to try to hire/keep employees that have worked there for years, learning the ins and outs of the system and processes, especially if they have earned one or more degrees from your university, and especially if they have already spent years being underpaid and under-appreciated (that way they will not be shocked by the way you would treat them as full time employees).

pros: The curriculum is awesome and the professors (Visiting Professors) are passionate and truly care for the students.
cons:
The management team is less than professional, and show favoritism to certain people in the inner circle.  They take advice from other who have no idea on what we do and make quick irrational decision that seems to always back fire.

It seems that they are no longer concerned for the military service member and or the veterans who served this great nation, instead they are chasing them solely for their Post 9/11 GI Bill money.  The recruitment tactics are extremely excessive and aggressive.

review_title: if you need something to get through the recession, work here until the market rebounds.
pros: If you can't find anything else, it's a great stepping stone but don't stay long.
cons:
They don't have a clue about managing people, providing incentives, or hiring top talent.  The worst place I've ever worked.  Low pay, low morale, poor working conditions, people are mean.  

THe organization is poorly organized and there is no chance of advancement.  They make you work Saturdays and even monitor the time you take to go to the bathroom.  Very humiliating!

You also need to compromise your integrity as you're suppose to sell a program to kids that typically don't have the money to pay for it for a degree that doesn't mean much in the marketplace.

review_title: DeVry University has been a wonderful place to work. It provided you with the experience of dealing with college student
job_title: Operations Support Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: DeVry University provides you with a great benefits package with includes healthcare, 401K Plan, vacation and paid sick time, health, dental and life insurance for employees and their dependents and spouse. The compenstion at DeVry University is also great.
cons: Working for a educational institute like DeVry University allows you to get information regarding student loans and grants.  I do not feel like some of the students are there for an education but for the money from Financial Aide.

review_title: I worked in a public service area of this university.
pros: I enjoyed the people that I worked with.
cons: All employees need to update their job skills on a regular basis.   Communication could be better at this university.  Morale was at often times really bad.    Staff need to have the most updated computers, etc.  to make their jobs easier.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I loved the camaraderie and the strong focus on employee engagement.  DeVry really cares not only about the success of its students, but also very much on the personal development and success of each employee.
cons: At the time, the university went through some struggles due to the external environment, but it actually managed things quite well and has really done some great things to improve the student and employee experience since then.

review_title: I wish I had my last supervisor back.
job_title: Student Finance Consultant in Addison, IL
pros: In the beginning it was good. Benefits are available that I haven't had with other companies. Anyone that wants to take classes can after a period of six months.
cons: Promotions are politically motivated. They say it can take up to two years for anyone to be promoted but unless your in good with the managers and the higher ups, you will be stuck for a while. Everything was good till this new supervisor took over the department. Now mostly everyone is looking to leave cause they don't want to deal with the nonsense.

job_title: Career Advisor in Sherman Oaks, CA
pros: Great coworkers, but that's really it.
cons: Bad management, horrible so-called raises, compensation not relative to cost of living for particular areas, not much opportunity for advancement, work life balance horrible, the list goes on and on

job_title: Admissions Advisor I in Chicago, IL
pros: Probably the best on line University there is.  No not perfect, when compared to the other schools I feel DeVry does it best in student centric services.  I am not judged on Number of enrollments rather my behavior as relates to TEACH values.  I am no fool as I know enrollment plays a key role in my personal success. The diversity of DeVry University, Chamberlain and Ross University along with the plan to grow in other non traditional areas brings financial stability as "Wall Street" beats us up less than other schools in the for profit arena.  They also offer a 4% 401K match vested immediately and provide close to a great healthcare plan when compared to others.
cons: The sector, for profit education, creates a conflict between what is best for the student and overall enrollment numbers but I feel that is the way it is in for profit education.  Recent pay raises have been almost non existent to say the least.  My base salary has increased $1,500.00 in two years and one review was "exceeds" the others on the high end of the "meets" scale.  The statement is, "we are working towards parity in the salary structure".  I do beleive the new hires are brought in at a substantial less income than I was 2 years ago, mid to upper 30's.  Micromanagement is rampant.  Inconsistency and hypocricy reigns.   Advancedment very limited unless you play the political game.  The better Advisors in terms of TEACH values and new enrollment do not get promoted, the "brown nosers" do.

pros: Culture of CARE is emphasized and expected - colleagues truly do care about the success of students and their persistence to graduation.  Great Benefits package for full time colleagues including tuition assistance
cons: Fading fast due to lack of CARE for the colleagues and no promotion opportunities.  The same concern showed for students is not present in colleague interaction and the need to point fingers across departments is increasing leading to a decrease in collaboration.

pros: I am a student worker at DeVry and the upsides to this is that it is very flexible with my class schedule, I was able to work my schedule around my classes rather then it being the other way around. Its convenient since I am at Devry all the time anyways either for events or classes so I don't have to do anymore traveling to and from work then I normally would. We're only allowed to work twenty hours a week which is great (also a negative) because it leaves a lot of free time to get class work done in between working.
cons: Downsides are that the pay is low for the amount of work required. A common line used amongst student workers is "full-time work for part-time pay." Which brings me to the 20 hours. While working a full 20 hours a week is optional working over that amount is prohibited unless classes are out for winter or summer break. I guess this is in place so that students can put more emphasis on their class work but  I think students should be given the opportunity to work more then that if they wanted to, either that or raise the pay. $8.00/hr or $320 every two weeks (if your work the full 20/hrs) is pretty ridiculous when you have to factor in that students are on their own for transportation to and from school - this includes metro - which is costly in itself, then we're on our own for parking - $45.00 a month or $17.00 a day -  and many students that are in housing have to work multiple jobs in addition to working at Devry just to make ends meet. While we do get "raises" I hardly call a quarter every year a raise. Yeah, I know its temporary we're just their to work until we graduate but I don't think anyone takes into consideration how much gets done at that campus thanks to student workers. We get no benefits, if a work day falls on a holiday or a day that school is closed, we don't get paid for that day, which wouldn't be such a bummer if we didn't get paid hardly anything in the first place. If I didn't need the money and if the economy were not in such a state that I could move on to something better I would have left a long time ago.

review_title: Suprisingly good for what is inevitably a sales role
job_title: Admissions Advisor I in Naperville, IL
pros: Benefits effective day 1, 11 paid holidays and two weeks vacation, 401k match, casual fridays and practically free college tuition. They are also very organized, there is no question about responsibilities and tons of support from management, IT, coworkers-etc
cons: Call center/telesales environment, very few of the entry level people have longevity- there is some concern about turnover in certain departments. If you can't cut the mustard your out no questions asked.

review_title: Not a good place for adjuncts.
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Kansas City, MO
pros: The canned nature of the curriculum leaves little need for prep. The staff is supportive of adjunct professors.
cons: The salary is below average for adjuncts and your are categorized as a contractor despite the fact that they dictate the time, place, and manner of the job. This should be categorized as an employee relationship, with DeVry paying their portion of taxes.

pros: Friendly environment and great coaching. Constant efforts are always made to help you improve. You are given the ability to create your own success. Communication was excellent between advisors and management.
cons: Pay is not competitive for the industry. Reps do EVERYTHING for the students, but aren't compensated accordingly.

pros: Great work culture in that staff and faculty define what it means to work as a team.
cons: School has a poor perception promblem  in most cities.  Quality of students are of a poor caliber which has effected the outcome of students getting hired.  School has a tendency to offer too many training classes and too many meetings during the course of one's work week. Degree Programs that are being offered should be eliminated from course schedule in some areas if an industry in that area is not strong.

job_title: Senior Marketing Specialist in Downers Grove, IL
pros:
Good benefits
Good pay
I personally had a great boss
cons:
The organization is going downhill fast. They are in a desperate fight to turn it around and keep saying "we've hit the bottom" but not sure how deep this pit goes. 
In the last year, my team has been passed to a different department 4 times. The organization of the organization (yeah i know it sounds weird) it's in a desperate state of looking busy to try and make it look like a needle is moving.

pros: Student centric, outcome-based curriculum , structured course development environment, optional campus-based or online learning environments,  progressive assessment system that can be tailored to the topics to be learned.
cons: Course development turn-around in technical areas far too slow, process overbearingly cumbersome, too many personnel involved in the process. Seems that declining enrollment brought constant, relentless change in policies that no one could possibly adhere to.

review_title: Preys on unemployed underemployed workers for a fast buck.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Call center environment with a big brother looking over your shoulder.
cons: Classes go so fast that no one really learns the material. Leaves students with a degree but very little knowledge in their degree field.

pros: Not very many except for a group of dedicated people working to make a difference in students' lifes under a constant pressure for "numbers" and "daily run rates".  Many professionals are still working hard to help students to succeed under the constant pressure of "making numbers".
cons: Management in every level is fixated on micromanagement , almost paranoid on control. No trust in professionalism or integrity of people working for the University. Main campus has been sold as well as dormitory, leaving students in dorms fending for themselfs. Bad publicity and recent law suits drive students away. As a result DeVry has become bad choice for potential students or employees.

pros: Salary, benefits, and corporate training were all great.  It was a fair company and I learned so much there.
cons: The campus and assistant directors were the worst I had ever seen. They had no idea what to do regarding device students, and they did not follow company policy.  They hired all of their friends who also had no idea what they were doing. The company did not get it right until hiring the last campus director.

pros: Good pay and benefits, excellent group of people to work with. Primary focus is servicing students needs and ensuring they receive what is needed to succeed in their future careers.
cons: Challenging to advance unless willing to relocate or change groups. To centralized and not enough flexibility for local campus to make own decisions based on their demographic location.

job_title: Operations Support Coordinator in San Jose, CA
pros: Colleagues are always readily available and helpful when it comes to any questions I have. They have also provided me with great resources and training since I have started.
cons: Between the different teams and areas, sometimes communication is lost along the way. I have had a few events now where I was told one thing and have been corrected by another party, who was unaware of the original directions or task.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Federal Way, WA
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed working for DeVry University for the last thirteen years and have held my current title of Assistant Professor for three years.  But recent staff reductions make it necessary for me to pursue another opportunity.  Management always made me feel that my contribution was appreciated and my industrial experience and teaching style helped students understand difficult concepts.
cons: Decreasing enrollments for all higher education institutions and increasing political pressure on market-based educators nationwide.

review_title: Run! Don't pass go, don't collect 200, just RUN! Don't accept a position
job_title: Senior Admissions Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Pay is great, benefits are great, but expensive,
cons: Management is incompetent. Especially in the NY Midtown Manhattan Office

job_title: Student Finance Consultant in Tinley Park, IL
pros: My team at that time and helping student find financial resources that would help assist in their education
cons: Consist frictions between academic, registrar and admission. It seemed as if everyone wanted to pass the buck and not take responsibility. In addition, people were starting to do things because it was coming so driven by admission and getting student enrolled and not helping or considered with if Devry was the right fit for that student.

review_title: Run don't walk away from this organization
pros:
Quality education for students
They will stay out of spotlight at all costs (negative publicity)
cons:
Management - who  have lost connection to the actual employees
For-profit mentality, it is all about the bottom line, they do NOT take students first.
They had us try "working Sunday's to reach students" - while they stayed at home relaxing with their families.  I have never worked somewhere where a 7-day work week was the norm for new employees (think 5 -6/hours a day 7 days a week...burnout)

pros:
-can work from home
- 401k match up to 4%
-very employee focus, they continuously send employee engagement surveys
cons:
- not much room for advancement
-salary 
-stepping stone company the pay is good for someone who is single with no kids, or someone who is married with a spouse to help support them

review_title: Good place to work; pay's a little low
job_title: Financial Aid Representative in Oak Brook, IL
pros: I've really enjoyed my job at Devry. Although it can get a bid repetitive at times, there are plenty of opportunities to move inside of the company. management is very caring and they foster an environment where personal development is encourages. Benefits are top notch and you can get tuition reimbursement at Keller after a year of employment
cons: Pay is a little low. Heavy Emphasis on hourly productivity

review_title: Bait & switch... They have no compassion for students at all
job_title: Senior Admissions Advisor in Crystal City, VA
pros: As with any company, there are always people who take pride in their work and feel like they make a difference. The problem is those people are few and far between.
cons: The sales tactics at play are designed to take advantage of students at every turn. The high pressure sales environment feels better suited to a used car dealership. Not to mention how our military students are exploited due to their GI Bill benefits. It is very depressing.

pros: The relationships built with the students and faculty. The ability to play an instrumental role in students lives by encouraging them throughout their degree programs.
cons:
High turnover at the top level, mainly the role of campus president. Pretty cut throat employees and shady management practices. Admissions team gives students false hopes about the timeframe required to complete degree programs. 
Demotions are commonplace.

pros: Flexible scheduling allowed for good work life balance. The salary wasn't too bad either, but they changed the comp plan to restrict you from getting bonuses at one point.
cons: The managers were horrible. They loved to play favorites and allowed the nuisance employees to run the show so that the people who actually worked had to constantly question their actions.

job_title: Student Finance Consultant in Raleigh, NC
pros: DeVry University pays above the industry average for most positions.  Their benefits, including 100% tuition paid is the best part of working for the company.
cons: Information sharing leaves a lot to be desired.  There seems to be an issue with the flow of information from management to the employees.

review_title: A good experience as a job, take advantage of all the opportunities offered to you
pros:
The tuition benefit is great, employees are encouraged to take advantage of it
There were several initiatives to promote employee financial, physical and emotional well being
Good 401k policy
If you show initiative, they will invest heavily in you
cons: Health insurance isn't too great

pros: It was a pleasure to work here at the Miami Campus.  The dean and his staff made me feel part of their team while my position was long term temporary thru an agency.  During this time I had the opportunity to work different duties while I assisted the Operations Support Coordinator.  I enjoyed it very much.
cons: My position was long term temporary thru a agency; therefore, I was not able to experience the benefits and pluses of being employed by the school directly.

pros: The professors at DeVry are collaborative and given a lot of freedom to be creative with their students. The atmosphere is collegial and supportive.
cons: The national organization recently gave a raise to faculty but have basically taken it away by cutting more experienced professor's hours and hiring cheaper less experienced professors. Many campus directors are not experienced in dealing with educational issues.

pros: Ummm...maybe above average starting salary for someone out of college.  I have to say I love my co-workers.  That's it.
cons: No one has enough time to read every thing I could possibly write.  I never knew that companies with such HORRIBLE management and such a decrepit infrastructure existed..this bad at least.  I know 2 people that like working at DeVry; that's it and there are hundreds in the building.  Do yourself a favor and RUN!

job_title: Executive Recruiter in Crystal City, VA
pros:
Competitive Benefits
Great Co-Workers
Positive Intentions
Industry Leading Pay and Training
Management
cons:
Lot of weekend work. Long hours. High pressure high turnover environment built under the guise of promoting student success, aka "butts in classes". 
Micro-management (mostly for compliance reasons)
Selling students a program when they may not be "college ready"
Management

pros: My colleagues were like family. Great team to work with. Always put the students first. Education benefits are good for the employees.

job_title: IT Help Desk Tech I in Addison, IL

review_title: Career Suicide! Bottom Of the Barrel  Company, Job and Outlook
pros: Coworkers were the only thing that kept me going.
cons:
If you're even considering a position here, you will have essentially committed career suicide if you accept. No recruiters in any legitimate university will look twice at your resume.  Not to mention, the majority of people out there have an extremely low opinion of DeVry's validity as a "university".

I’ve never been associated with a company with such HORRIBLE upper-level management (president, directors, deans). This is an extremely pretentious and egotistical environment where management rather show power then provide leadership. The president has no trust in the employees and always chooses to hire outside of company for higher level positions.  Also, management makes certain that you do NOT get an annual raise. They purposely manipulate your annual evaluations so that you are destined to receive no increase. There are employees who have been here there for years and have had less than a 1% hike in their annual salary.

The Directors idea of management is applying scare tactics. They want to break you down and make you feel like you’re not good enough. They do this so they could have some type of “control” over you. Nothing positive about your performance comes out of a directors mouth, not even if you’re short of amazing.

There is no job security and are consistent annual layoffs in July. Typically, the ones getting laid off are the ones with a higher salary, so even if you got a promotion, you would eventually be let go. 

 Last 2 months of my employment this is what happened:
We went from 4 directors of admissions to 1, 3 admissions reps were let go, 1 dean has resigned, 3 success coaches resigned all in 1 week, 1 student finance consultant resigned, and the student central manager has resigned also.
***PAST 2 MONTHS!

Stay FAR away from this company!


In my time here I've worked with

review_title: Devry is like bootcamp. I learned a lot, but glad I am out!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Awesome team members (not including senior managers), fantastic benefits, and decent pay (not great).
cons:
No life and work balance. Even though they preach this, the reality is that you will need to work most Saturdays due to several events taking place. Nothing wrong with working Saturdays, I just wish they had told me when I accepted this position. 

Managers do not give credit where credit is due. They don't like to give admissions advisors positive reenforcement for some reason. I was told that "once they're told they do a good job, they stop working". The reality is the admissions advisors felt like they got no respect from managers, thus there is a 70% turnover rate.

Senior managers are very quick to "write somebody up" because their numbers may be to low. Even though this goes directly against Title IV federal laws for school recruiters (they cant be written up for not recruiting "high numbers"),  a new advisor will be written up within a few months if they cant hack it. No training.....they just throw you out there. 

The higher converting leads (potential students who walk in or fill out an application online) go to the managers (who are also responsible for bringing in students) and the higher performers. When you interview a student, you are putting on high pressure tactics for them apply. If the potential wants to study nursing (not offered at Devry University), you are responsible to convinced that student why nursing is not the program they really want to do and put them in a program that Devry offers. If that student doesn't apply, you will hear it from your manager about "not helping out that student."

Turnovers and stress are both normal in the admissions department at Devry in Los Angeles. If this is for you, then you should apply. They have plenty of openings (I wonder why).

pros: I work with Great employees/friends.

I’ve never been associated with a company with such HORRIBLE upper-level management (president, directors, deans).  The president has no trust in the employees and always chooses to hire outside of company for higher level positions.  Past 2 months at my location:

***PAST 2 MONTHS!
